Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 15. Meditation in the Farmlands and Elsewhere
Again, the king questioned the chariotteer as he had done previously.
Manual - English: The Bodhisattva goes to the fields where he sets free farmers, the oxen, and so forth.

Sun of Faith - English: The king thought, "I will send the Youth to the farmers' village and that will distract him."
"Come here young one," he said to the Bodhisattva. "Go to the farmer's village and look after their work."
When the king said that, the bodhisattva was overcome with thoughts of aging, sickness, and death.
He was fixated on renouncing the world, yet he listened to his father Shudodhana's words, and boarded his charriot to the farmers' village.
Along the road, five hundred caches of treasure opened. A voice said, "Youth, we are your ancestral treasuries. Please take us."
"I have no need of you," he replied. "Be gone."
"Whoever has told me tales of dying, Has become a tale of death. Even I, not long after death, Will become a tale told by others." Then the caches of treasure disappeared in vast ocean.
He reached the farmers' village and saw the farmers toiling. He saw that the farmers' hands and feet were cracked. He saw the oxen exhausted and toiling, and a great compassion was born in his heart.
Inscription - English: The Bodhisattva youth arrives at the fields.

Sun of Faith - English: “You should try to find some happiness,” the Bodhisattva said, and he released the farmers from their work. Then he freed the draught animals.

Scene working notes: Ari would like to suggest that the bris yig  "In another scene, he also sets free house servants.", though not appearing in the SoF directly, does appear in the murals here, to the left of the compound below the sick man. Ari suggest we add this row here to reflect that, though the bris yig & the mural are the attestations. Potential complication in inscription with the figures: gzhon nu las / las sna tshogs par gzigs pa. Is he releasing them from their labor (Ch. 15) or is he witnessing some sort of suffering caused by karma [and the need to be reborn as a manual laborer (Ch. 14).  bris yig is very truncated.

Sun of Faith - English: Seeing the farmers' suffering made his feelings even more intense, and he sat in the shade of a jambu tree. There he spontaneously engaged in the meditation of the first concentration.
Inscription - English: Sitting in the shade of a jambu tree.
Manual - English: The Bodhisattva goes to meditate in the shade under a jambu tree where his father bows down to him.
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu source does characterize the meditation as "samadhi" (ting nge 'dzin): 'dod pa las dben pa sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams las dben pa/_rtog pa dang bcas dpyod pa dang bcas shing dben pa las skyes pa'i dga' ba dang bde ba zag pa med pa dang 'dra ba'i bsam gtan dang po la snyoms par zhugs so/ (6b.4-5)

Sun of Faith - English: While the Bodhisattva rested in the equipoise of concentration, a large gathering of people stayed near another tree so as not to leave the Bodhisattva.
The king thought, "The Youth has now taken a long time and the midday meal has passed. I shall go to have a look." Then he boarded his charriot.

When the king drew near the Bodhisattva it was past noon, and the shadows of the other trees had moved to the east. But the shadow of the jambu tree had not moved to the east. It had not left the Bodhisattva's body. Seeing this, the king fell at the feet of the Bodhisattva.
Just as the earth shook at your birth, The jambu tree's shadow never left your body. Great Minded One, these are your two wondrous signs. All-Seeing One, I bow at your feet.
The king roused the Bodhisattva from his concentration and they boarded the charriot.

On the road to the city they neared a charnel ground. They saw decaying corpses and other horrifying things. The Bodhisattva became overwhelmed with sorrow. So he sat cross-legged on the floor of the charriot and entered into concentration.
Inscription - English: The Youth sees the charnel ground. Charnel ground Shuddhodana

Sun of Faith - English: Again, the king roused him from his concentration. When they returned to Kapilavastu, the soothsayers said, “If the Youth does not renounce the world in a week's time, he will become a universal monarch."
"If you wish to see such a good result, Guard him for seven nights. You'll see a soverign's umbrella unfurl And the seven royal treasures appear, have no doubt."
